title: £60m: what Sky's customers have to pay to leave
text:
850.50 -12.00 
Comment: Sky (LSE: BSY.L - news ) is being investigated by the watchdog for trying to prevent customers from cancelling but, for now at least, Sky's tactics still bring in money, says Nicole Blackmore 
What is it going to take for Sky to start treating its customers fairly? 
The TV, phone and internet provider is finally being investigated by the regulator , Ofcom, for refusing to allow customers to easily cancel when they reach the end of their contract. 
Let’s be clear about what is going on here Sky is making millions every year from customers who want to leave by using delaying tactics to prevent them from cancelling. 
Even (Taiwan OTC: 6436.TWO - news ) though its own contracts state that customers can cancel by email, letter, fax or phone, any written requests are ignored until the customer speaks to Sky over the phone. 
We all know the drill from there Sky customers are forced to spend hours going round and round in circles , at their own expense of course, when all they want to do is end their service. 
Sky has over 12 million customers in the UK and Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) . Let’s assume that customers spend around £50 a month, and that, on average, 10pc of customers cancel their service every year (figures which comes from Sky's own reports ). 
Sky’s deliberate delaying tactics stand to net the company an additional £60m revenue a year and that’s if it only delays cancellations by one month. Not bad. 
It’s no wonder that we routinely hear from readers who are at their wits end. They simply want to cancel, but are told that they don’t have the necessary “security data” or password, or that they must go through a lengthy “process” over the phone. 
Sky (Amsterdam: BK8.AS - news ) customer gets £1,500 payout after two years trying to cancel his contract 
Buy why? Other companies are happy to accept written notice of cancellation. In fact most prefer it it gives both sides proof of communication and there is less chance of requests being misunderstood. 
Sky is unapologetic about its tactics and the way it treats customers. Its tagline, "believe in better", must seem like a cruel joke to those who are trapped in its grip. 
This week, Sky customer John Snoxell was being chased by debt collectors, even though he had given three months notice in writing of his cancellation. Sky insisted he owed almost £60, but this newspaper’s investigation showed that Sky actually owed Mr Snoxell money. I wonder how many more customers are in a similar position, but who pay the bill through fear of a poor credit rating. 
If Ofcom hopes to make any difference here, it has to issue fines that outweigh the additional revenues Sky brings in by this deliberate prevention of customers from leaving. 
Come on Ofcom, step up and put an end to this profiteering. No one should be bullied into paying for a service they no longer want or need. 
- nicole.blackmore@telegraph.co.uk
